Visitor parking is located along the drive between
Garland Hall and Latrobe Hall, near Homewood
House, between Maryland Hall and Whitehead Hall, in
front of the Athletic Center, near AMR 11, and near the
White House and the Hopkins Club. Handicapped parking
is located alongside Shriver, Gilman, and Remsen halls,
behind Mudd Hall, and in front of Garland Hall.

Dining facilities are available in Levering Cafeteria,
the Terrace Room and the Snack Bar in AMR 11, the
Kosher Dining Hall in AMR [, and the Hopkins Club.

Garland Hall (13) is the main administration building
of the University. In addition to the offices of the presi-
dent, the provost, and other University officials, it houses
the registrar’s and admissions offices.

The Milton S. Eisenhower Library (32), named for the
University’s eighth president, currently holds 1.9 million
of the more than 2.7 million books owned by the Univer-
sity. The Library is open from 8 a.m. to midnight, Monday
through Thursday; from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m., Friday and
Saturday; and from 10 a.m. to midnight, Sunday.

Gilman Hall (15), the landmark building of the Home-
wood campus, takes its name from Daniel Coit Gilman,
the University’s first president. It houses the Albert D.
Hutzler Undergraduate Library, the Archaeological Collec-
tion, faculty offices, and classrooms, as well as the campus
bookstore and post office.

Mudd Hall (33) houses the Department of Biology and
the McCollum-Pratt Institute, a biochemical research
facility. The two wings added to Mudd Hall are called the
Levi Building (33A) and Biology East (33B).

The Space Telescope Science Institute (44 ), which is
funded by NASA and operated by the Association of Uni-
versities for Research in Astronomy (AURA), will interpret
data from the 95-inch telescope launched into orbit from
a space shuttle. Its transmission of celestial images gen-
erated 14 billion light years away will be analyzed here by
the world’s foremost astronomers and astrophysicists.

Shriver Hall (43) contains the University’s largest
auditorium, used for lectures, concerts, and films through-
out the year, and the Board Room of the University’s



trustees. Five murals, mandated by Shriver’s will, decorate
the entrance hall. The murals depict ten famous Baltimore
beauties (of Shriver’s own choosing), the original faculty
of philosophy, the class of 1891, the original faculty of
medicine, and ten Baltimore philanthropists.

Productions of Theatre Hopkins are staged in the
Merrick Barn (30), originally a carriage house on the
Homewood estate.

A National Historic Landmark, Homewood (21 ) was
built in 1801 by Charles Carroll of Carrollton, a signer of
the Declaration of Independence, as a wedding present
for his son. The house has been completely restored and
is open to the public as a museum.

Dunning Park (11), located on a wooded hillside,
is dotted with eleven animal sculptures created by an
internationally known artist, the late Beniamino Bufano.

The Johns Hopkins Club (23) provides dining services
for alumni and faculty members.

The Hopkins Union is located in Levering Hall (25)
and the Glass Pavilion ( 16), which adjoins it. The Union



provides a TV lounge, a game room, Student Council
offices, and the Listening/Viewing Room, in which lec-
tures, meetings, and productions of the Barnstormers, the
student theater group, are held.

Dormitories are located in a quadrangle behind
Homewood.AMR I (6) and IT (7) contain traditional
shared rooms. Buildings A (8) and B (9) offer shared
suites for three or four students. In addition to living
quarters the dormitories feature dining facilities, a
computer room, and study lounges. Additional graduate
and undergraduate dormitories are located across Charles
Street.

Beyond the dormitories, at the north end of the
campus, lies Homewood Field (19), home of the peren-
nially powerful Hopkins lacrosse team. The Astroturf field
and all-weather track are also used for the soccer, field
hockey, women’s lacrosse, football, track, and cross-
country teams. Adjacent to the field is the Newton H.

White Jr. Athletic Center (34). 63%‘-[ l_’
